entry.title: The Ducklings Follow You
entry.content:
Being a role model for healthy screen use is essential in today's digital age, especially when it comes to influencing our children's behavior. Here are some key instances when we tend to use phones the most:

  1. Unwinding After Work or Events: It's common to reach for our phones when we come home after a long day or when we're relaxing after an event. These moments of downtime can become opportunities for our children to observe our screen habits.
  2. During Breakfast or Meals:Many of us check our phones during meals, whether it's breakfast, lunch, or dinner. This habit can inadvertently send the message that screens are more important than connecting with family during mealtime.
  3. While Watching a Show:Watching TV or streaming content on our devices often goes hand in hand with using our phones. Kids notice this association and may adopt it.
  4. In Bed - Before and After Sleep:Scrolling through our phones in bed before falling asleep and immediately after waking up has become a common routine. Children may pick up on this behavior, potentially affecting their sleep patterns.

To be mindful of our screen use and set a positive example for our children, we can start by tracking our own digital technology use. Many smartphones have tracking features that monitor screen time. By using these features, we can gain insight into our habits and evaluate whether changes are needed. We could even involve our children in this process by asking them to keep track of their screen time as well. This can lead to valuable discussions where we compare our usage patterns and decide together if adjustments are necessary.

Furthermore, engaging in open conversations with our children about the applications we use, the people and groups we follow, or interesting content we've come across can foster a safe and trusting environment at home. It's crucial to create an atmosphere where it's okay to discuss screen time and digital technology use without judgment. By sharing our experiences and insights, we can help our children navigate the digital world responsibly and develop healthy screen habits that will benefit them throughout their lives.

entry.title: Keeping the Ducklings Waterproof.
entry.content:
Just like young ducklings rely on their mother's oil gland for waterproofing until they grow feathers, our children also depend on us to guide and protect them in the digital world. Here are some ways to ensure they stay "waterproof" in the ever-flowing stream of screens and technology:

  1. Customized Screen Time Routines: It's common to reach for our phones when we come home after a long day or when we're relaxing after an event. These moments of downtime can become opportunities for our children to observe our screen habits.
  2. Co-Watching and Interacting:Whenever possible, co-watch or co-play with your children as they engage with media. This provides an opportunity for you to discuss content, answer questions, and share your values.
  3. Awareness of Dangerous Behavior:Teach your children about the types of dangerous online behavior they may encounter, such as cyberbullying, online predators, or scams. Encourage them to immediately report anything suspicious.
  4. Online Etiquette:Help your kids understand the importance of online etiquette, including being respectful in digital interactions, avoiding oversharing personal information, and using proper language.
  5. Parental Controls:Learn to use and implement parental control tools and software to limit access to age-appropriate content and monitor screen time.
  6. Content Review:Take an active role in finding good quality content for your children and review media for child safety. Familiarize yourself with media ratings to make informed choices.
  7. Family Media Plan:Create a family media plan that everyone in the household follows. For example, designate meal times as screen-free moments, with no exceptions.
  8. Productive Screen Time:Encourage productive screen time activities, such as educational apps, creative content creation, or interactive learning platforms.
  9. Screen Time Tracking:Utilize screen time tracking features on devices to monitor and manage your child's digital usage.
  10. Active Screen Time:Promote active screen time by engaging in physical activities that involve screens, like interactive video games that require movement or watching exercise videos together.
  11. Privacy Education:Teach your children about online privacy, emphasizing the importance of not sharing personal information like home addresses or phone numbers online.
  12. Healthy Sedentary Screen Time:Make sedentary screen time healthier by setting time limits and encouraging regular breaks for physical activity, stretching, and eye rest.

Just as mother ducks nurture their ducklings until they are ready to be independent, our guidance and support in managing screen time and digital technology will help our children become responsible and safe digital citizens when the time comes for them to navigate the digital world on their own.

entry.title: Of Ducklings and Diapers: The Quirky Guide to Parenting Woes

link.title: Of Ducklings and Diapers: The Quirky Guide to Parenting Woes

entry.content:
Of Ducklings and Diapers: The Quirky Guide to Parenting Woes

Have you ever spotted a fluffy parade of ducklings wobbling behind their mother, and thought, "Geez, they've got it easy!"? Oh, how we envy Mama Duck! Her young ones follow her without questioning, "Why?". No tantrums. No “I don’t wanna.” But, what if ducks had the same dilemmas as us humans? Let's take a quack at it, shall we?

Imagine Mama Duck's morning. She's got to get her ducklings in a row, literally! There’s Daisy who's trying to eat a pebble, Donald is busy chasing his tail (do ducks have tails?), and Daffy... well, he’s just being daffy, looking skyward and asking deep existential questions about the universe. Sound familiar?

Fun Fact: Ducks have an innate following mechanism called 'imprinting'. Lucky for them, their kids imprint and follow. Humans? Not so much. Our little rascals have 'inquiring'. They question. A lot!

So, you see, in an alternate duck universe, parenting woes are real! Just as ducklings might waddle out of line, our children, curious and ever-exploring, often stray from our carefully charted paths. They’re just eager to dive into life's pond, even if it means getting a little wet and muddy.

Now, imagine a parent-child outing at the park. In our duck-world scenario, Mama Duck would be quacking frantically into her duck-phone, seeking advice from Dr. Quack about Daffy's recent fear of water. Daisy, in the meantime, has discovered her reflection in the pond and is having a deep conversation with it. Oh, and Donald? He's picked up bread crumbs from questionable sources (shady pigeons, no doubt).

But here's the thing, no matter how chaotic, Mama Duck, like all parents, wears her invisible superhero cape (feathered edition). With a mix of love, patience, and a pinch of humor, she'd manage to guide her quirky ducklings through the highs and lows of ducklinghood.

Fun Fact: Ever noticed how ducks appear calm on the surface but paddle like mad underwater? That's parenthood in a nutshell!

But what can we, the not-so-feathered kind, learn from this? Well, the duck tale (pun intended!) reminds us to embrace the chaos, the unpredictability, and yes, even the occasional defiance that comes with parenting. Because, let’s be honest, if our kids just followed us mindlessly, life would be a tad too... boring.

Let’s celebrate those little rebellious moments, the incessant "why's", the muddy footprints on the living room carpet, and the impromptu dance sessions. They're evidence of lively minds, challenging boundaries, and forging their own paths. And isn’t that what we want? Little ducklings growing into confident ducks who aren’t afraid to spread their wings (once they get them, of course).

So, the next time your child tests your patience or ventures off the path, think of Mama Duck. Take a deep breath, ruffle your feathers, and dive back in with love and a dash of humor. Because, in the end, whether in diapers or downy feathers, they're all just trying to find their way in this big pond we call life.

Happy parenting, and may your duckling days be filled with love, laughter, and only the occasional misplaced pebble snack!

entry.title: Failure is not an option
entry.content:
Never in all their history have men been able truly to conceive of the world as one: a single sphere, a globe, having the qualities of a globe, a round earth in which all the directions eventually meet, in which there is no center because every point, or none, is center — an equal earth which all men occupy as equals. The airman's earth, if free men make it, will be truly round: a globe in practice, not in theory.

Science cuts two ways, of course; its products can be used for both good and evil. But there's no turning back from science. The early warnings about technological dangers also come from science.

What was most significant about the lunar voyage was not that man set foot on the Moon but that they set eye on the earth.

A Chinese tale tells of some men sent to harm a young girl who, upon seeing her beauty, become her protectors rather than her violators. That's how I felt seeing the Earth for the first time. I could not help but love and cherish her.

For those who have seen the Earth from space, and for the hundreds and perhaps thousands more who will, the experience most certainly changes your perspective. The things that we share in our world are far more valuable than those which divide us.

The Final Frontier

There can be no thought of finishing for ‘aiming for the stars.’ Both figuratively and literally, it is a task to occupy the generations. And no matter how much progress one makes, there is always the thrill of just beginning.

There can be no thought of finishing for ‘aiming for the stars.’ Both figuratively and literally, it is a task to occupy the generations. And no matter how much progress one makes, there is always the thrill of just beginning.

The dreams of yesterday are the hopes of today and the reality of tomorrow. Science has not yet mastered prophecy. We predict too much for the next year and yet far too little for the next ten.

Spaceflights cannot be stopped. This is not the work of any one man or even a group of men. It is a historical process which mankind is carrying out in accordance with the natural laws of human development.

Reaching for the Stars

As we got further and further away, it [the Earth] diminished in size. Finally it shrank to the size of a marble, the most beautiful you can imagine. That beautiful, warm, living object looked so fragile, so delicate, that if you touched it with a finger it would crumble and fall apart. Seeing this has to change a man.

To go places and do things that have never been done before – that’s what living is all about.

Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of the Starship Enterprise. Its five-year mission: to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before.

As I stand out here in the wonders of the unknown at Hadley, I sort of realize there’s a fundamental truth to our nature, Man must explore, and this is exploration at its greatest.
